sec.title: Self-Study Program
sec.p: Reading an issue of the Journal of Correctional Health Care and completing the corresponding exam is considered a single continuing education activity. The self-study exam questions are based on selected articles in this issue. Content is intended to be presented without bias of any commercial product or drug.

You may answer exam questions relating to every article, or you may select questions relating to specific articles. Credit will be awarded for each article, assuming 75% of the questions are answered correctly. The number of credit hours is calculated for each article based on word count. The exam is graded on a confidential basis by NCCHC staff.

Term of approval requires that exams must be completed and received by NCCHC within 2 years of the distribution date of this publication. Credit may be claimed for this issue of JCHC until January 31, 2015.

sec.title: Learning Objectives
sec.p:
The Journal of Correctional Health Care is the only national, peer-reviewed scientific journal to address correctional health care topics. After participating in this self-study activity, participants should be able to:
Describe trends and developments in the correctional health care field.
Analyze case studies and best practices related to the correctional setting.
Discuss empirical research findings, including their relevance and limitations.
Critically evaluate the literature and recent books addressing correctional health or related fields.

sec.title: Continuing Education
sec.p: Participants should only claim credit commensurate with the extent of their participation in the activity.

list-item.p: CCHPs: The Certified Correctional Health Professional Board of Trustees has approved this educational activity for 3.4 contact hours of Category 1 credit.
Nurses: The National Commission on Correctional Health Care is accredited as a provider of continuing nursing education by the American Nurses Credentialing Center’s Commission on Accreditation.
NCCHC designates this activity for a maximum of 3.4 contact hours.

Physicians: The National Commission on Correctional Health Care is accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education to provide continuing medical education for physicians. NCCHC designates this journal-based CME activity for a maximum of 3.4 AMA PRA Category 1 Credit(s)™. Physicians should claim only the credit commensurate with the extent of their participation in the activity.

sec.title: Disclosure Statement
sec.p: In accordance with the disclosure policy of the National Commission on Correctional Health Care, everyone who is in a position to control the content of JCHC’s continuing education program (including authors, editorial board members, and staff) have been asked to disclose all relevant financial interests or other relationship with any commercial interest that might be germane to the content of the articles. Such disclosure is not intended to suggest or condone bias in any article but rather is elicited to provide information that readers might deem important to their evaluation of a given article.

For this issue of the Journal of Correctional Health Care, no authors, editorial board members, or staff have reported any relevant financial interests or other relationship with a commercial entity that might be germane to the content of the articles. The following authors disclosed grant funding for their work:

tr.td: Syphilis Outbreak at a California Men’s Prison, 2007–2008: Propagation by Lapses in Clinical Management, Case Management, and Public Health Surveillance
The work of authors from the California Department of Public Health was funded by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s Comprehensive STD Prevention Systems (Grant #5H25/PS904362-17).
Correlates of Condom Self-Efficacy in an Incarcerated Juvenile Population
Alabama Department of Public Health HIV Prevention Service Projects educational grant

sec.title: Payment
sec.p: For $30—only $20 for members of the Academy of Correctional Health Professionals—you will receive a certificate of completion indicating the number of hours earned. The self-study exam will not be processed and credit will not be awarded without receipt of payment. There are no refunds or cancellations.

sec.title: Requirements for Successful Completion

list-item.p: Read each article and check the correct answer to the corresponding questions on the exam. Each question has one answer that is most correct. Multiple answers for one question will not be counted. Be sure to fully erase all unnecessary marks.
Read the statement at the bottom of the answer sheet after completing the exam and sign to indicate your agreement.
Complete the evaluation to help us monitor the quality of this self-study program.
Mail the completed exam, evaluation, and payment to: NCCHC, PO Box 11117, Chicago, IL 60611. We recommend that you keep a copy of the exam for your reference.

sec.p: Journal of Correctional Health Care, Volume 19, Issue 1 Self-Study Exam

sec.title: Replicating MISTERS: An Epidemiological Criminology Framework Analysis of a Program for Criminal Justice-Involved Minority Males in the Community (p. 4) (0.7 hour of credit)

list-item.p:
Epidemiological criminology addresses behaviors from which of the following levels of analysis?
Family/group
Individual
Societal
All of the above

The MISTERS program addresses all of the behavioral domains listed below except:
Anger management
Sexual risk management
Financial management
Substance abuse

According to the authors, the epidemiological criminology framework “provides an intellectual space to explore” which of the following:
Common causal pathways that lead to both health risk behaviors and criminal justice involvement
The static risks and dynamic factors that underlie criminogenic risk
The epidemiology of health problems among inmates alone
Evidence-based interventions to reduce substance abuse prior to criminal justice involvement

Which of the following is within the framework of epidemiological criminology?
The sociology of deviance
Being the victim of a criminal act
Examination of disparities in health outcomes
Disproportionate minority contact with the justice system

sec.title: Syphilis Outbreak at a California Men’s Prison, 2007–2008: Propagation by Lapses in Clinical Management, Case Management, and Public Health Surveillance (p. 54) (0.7 hour of credit)

list-item.p:
Which of the following demographic groups was most affected by this syphilis outbreak?
Hispanic men with hepatitis B
HIV-positive men who reported injection drug use
HIV-positive men who have sex with men
African American men who reported injection drug use

Which of the following factors likely contributed to the propagation of syphilis among this incarcerated population?
Delays in reporting syphilis cases between the laboratory and the prison
Conjugal visits between inmates and women at high risk for syphilis
Delays between initial exam and treatment among patients with primary and secondary syphilis
Involuntary sex among inmates

Which of the following is TRUE of syphilis epidemiology?
Case-patients are most infectious during the primary and secondary stages of syphilis
Syphilis rates in the United States are at an all-time low
Hispanic men are more than likely than African American or White men to be reported to have syphilis
Rates of syphilis are higher in the general population than in incarcerated populations

Which case-finding method identified the greatest number of case-patients during this syphilis outbreak investigation?
Testing inmates named as sexual contacts by known case-patients
A mass screening targeted to one residential area of the prison
Review of sick-call appointments
Review of laboratory data

sec.title: Correlates of Condom Self-Efficacy in an Incarcerated Juvenile Population (p. 27) (0.7 hour of credit)

list-item.p:
One of the goals of the Making Proud Choices! Curriculum is to increase:
Knowledge about educational and career options.
The number of adolescents tested for HIV or other STIs.
Counseling services for sexually active adolescents.
Awareness of personal risk for contracting HIV or an STI.

What percentage of incarcerated males reported having sex with an anonymous partner?
7%
19%
23%
29%

Postintervention, there was NO significant difference between males and females in which of the following?
Knowledge about HIV and STIs
Condom use knowledge
Intention to use condoms
Condom self-efficacy

Which of the following is the most influential predictor of condom self-efficacy?
Intention to use condoms at next sexual intercourse
Knowledge about the symptoms and modes of transmission for HIV and STIs
Knowledge and skills about how to use a condom
Communication and condom use negotiation skills

sec.title: Continuity of Care in a Cohort of HIV-Infected Former Jail Detainees (p. 36) (0.6 hour of credit)

list-item.p:
Which statement is FALSE regarding HIV in correctional settings?
HIV/AIDS prevalence in correctional facilities is about 3 times that of the general population in the United States.
Less than 5% of all HIV-infected individuals in the United States are currently in jail or prison.
HIV long-term and comprehensive management is more amenable to the prison setting than the jail setting.
The short-term stays associated with the jail setting pose obstacles for HIV screening, treatment, and prevention.

What was the most common comorbidity among HIV-infected jail detainees in this study?
Tuberculosis
Hepatitis C
Syphilis
Hypertension

According to this study, what was the independent factor associated with continuity care nonengagement?
HIV viral load at the time of jail clinic visit
Number of previous incarcerations
No previous HIV care
No receipt of HAART during detention

What statement was TRUE according to the results of this study?
Ten percent of the detainees did not establish continuity care with the designated continuity clinics.
The majority of the study population was Hispanic male.
Among detainees who were on HAART prior to detention, 48% had undetectable plasma HIV RNA.
The most commonly reported HIV acquisition route was injection drug use.

sec.title: The Ten Essential Public Health Services Model as a Framework for Correctional Health Care (p. 43) (0.7 hour of credit)

list-item.p:
The Ten Essential Public Health Services framework applied to correctional health care:
Proposes a framework for the expansion of health services in correctional populations.
Describes the essential services that local health departments must provide.
Proposes a collaborative structure for local health departments and correctional facilities.
Describes the essential services that correctional facility health departments provide.

The public health model for correctional health care evolved from:
The Stanford Disease Care Model.
A model of infectious disease control.
A public health sanitarian model.
The Anderson Health Services Model.

The most common form of collaboration between local health departments and correctional facilities has been in the area of:
Communicable disease.
Chronic disease.
Environmental health.
Immunizations.

The implementation of _____ allowed the Division of Institutional Medicine to conduct many of the essential services related to health monitoring:
Risk management
Community empowerment
All hazards planning
Electronic medical record system

Journal of Correctional Health Care, Volume 19, Issue 1 Self-Study Program Evaluation

tr.td: 1. How well did the articles meet their stated learning objectives?

td.bold: Replicating MISTERS: An Epidemiological Criminology Framework Analysis of a Program for Criminal Justice-Involved Minority Males in the Community

list-item.p: Outline the levels of analysis combined in the epidemiological criminology framework to address the common pathways that lead to poor health and criminal justice outcomes
List at least three “evidence-based” HIV/STD-related programs used with persons involved in the criminal justice system
Explain the co-relation between criminogenics and poor health outcomes

td.bold: Syphilis Outbreak at a California Men’s Prison, 2007–2008: Propagation by Lapses in Clinical Management, Case Management, and Public Health Surveillance

list-item.p: Describe the nature and magnitude of this syphilis outbreak
Outline the subsequent control measures that were implemented
Propose recommendations to prevent future outbreaks in a correctional setting

td.bold: Correlates of Condom Self-Efficacy in an Incarcerated Juvenile Population

list-item.p: Identify the sexual risk behaviors of incarcerated youth
Describe differences between males and females in baseline and postintervention survey results
Explain how findings from this study influence health care practice and research

td.bold: Continuity of Care in a Cohort of HIV-Infected Former Jail Detainees

list-item.p: Describe characteristics of HIV-infected jail detainees
Identify risk factors for continuity care nonengagement among HIV-infected former jail detainees
Describe the importance of optimizing long-term HIV care among HIV-infected current and former jail detainees

td.bold: The Ten Essential Public Health Services Model as a Framework for Correctional Health Care

list-item.p: Identify the 10 essential public health services
Relate the 10 essential public health services to the provision of correctional health care
Assess the feasibility and utility of the 10 essential public health services framework to the provision of correctional health care

tr.td: 2. Please rate the relevance of the information addressed in each of the articles to your profession.

list-item.p: Replicating MISTERS: An Epidemiological Criminology Framework Analysis of a Program for Criminal Justice-Involved Minority Males in the Community
Syphilis Outbreak at a California Men’s Prison, 2007–2008: Propagation by Lapses in Clinical Management, Case Management, and Public Health Surveillance
Correlates of Condom Self-Efficacy in an Incarcerated Juvenile Population
Continuity of Care in a Cohort of HIV-Infected Former Jail Detainees
The Ten Essential Public Health Services Model as a Framework for Correctional Health Care

To earn credit for state licensing requirements
To meet employer’s continuing education requirements
To gain a better understanding of the information contained in the articles

Poor

Good
Great

10. Content is intended to be presented without bias of any commercial product or drug. Did you encounter any such bias in your reading of the Journal?
Yes
No
